description:
Remi is a boy living happily with his mother in the French countryside. But everything changes when his estranged father comes home and, in desperate need of money, reveals that Remi is adopted, and sells him. Heartbroken, Remi ends up with Vitalis, a traveling musician, and his troupe of animal entertainers. Together, they travel the country trying to make a living, along the way learning the harsh lessons of life. A deeply moving story about friendship, loss and the pursuit of happiness.

(Source: AniDB)

node.description:
Was a fan of Le Mans.

Dezaki was known for his distinct visual style, which makes use of split screen, stark lighting, extensive use of dutch angle, and pastel freeze frames that he called "postcard memories", which may be his most famous trademark.

Younger brother of director [Satoshi Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/111371). He is married to the mangaka [Rikako Kugayama](https://anilist.co/staff/304119).

Non-anime staff credits:~!
Animation director for "The Visionaries" (US cartoon)
Animation for "Rainbow Brite" (US cartoon)!~

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/杉野昭夫) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akio_Sugino)

A veteran animator with a career spanning over 50 years.

Noted for his work on shows like [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), [Ace wo Nerae!](https://anilist.co/anime/311/), [Nobody's Boy: Remi](https://anilist.co/anime/2828/) and [Treasure Island](https://anilist.co/anime/2618/).

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/shichiro_kobayashi/)

A former art director and a guest professor at Kobe Design University.

Kobayashi graduated from Musashino Art University and first became an elementary school art teacher. It was only later that he joined the animation industry in 1964. He started quickly making a name for himself as a background artist and consequently established his own background art studio Kobayashi Production, in 1968. During this time thick poster paint was dominating the backgrounds in anime, but Kobayashi started a new style with much thinner painting and colored pencil strokes.

He has worked as an art director on over 100 titles and is one of the most distinguished art directors in the medium. Notable works include [Gamba no Bouken](https://anilist.co/anime/5267/), [Ie Naki Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/2828/), [Takarajima](https://anilist.co/anime/2618/), [Tenshi no Tamago](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), [Utena](https://anilist.co/anime/440/), [Berserk](https://anilist.co/anime/33/) and [Nodame Cantabile](https://anilist.co/anime/1698/).

Kobayashi retired from the industry in 2010, which was followed by his studio's closedown a year later.

In a 2015 [interview](https://youtu.be/V1tiKOsCz2M), Kobayashi talked about his life and passion in painting touring his atelier and showcasing his work.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/男鹿和雄) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazuo_Oga)

After graduating from Kakunodate High School he joined an art school, which he quit one year prior to graduation.

In 1972, he started working at Kobayashi Production, where he was studying under [Shichirou Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/103964/). Later he joined [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) for a brief time, working as an art director on titles such as [Barefoot Gen](https://anilist.co/anime/1824/) and [Wicked City](https://anilist.co/anime/1107/). After this he was scouted out by [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), who was searching for a new art director for Studio Ghibli.

At Ghibli he was appointed as the art director for [My Neighbour Totoro](https://anilist.co/anime/523/), in which he was praised for his work by both Miyazaki and [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/). He worked at Ghibli for many years taking part in the production of most of their films. During this time he also worked on non-Ghibli works. Oga has since left the studio and is now freelance.

He has also published several art books and acts as an advisor at Deho Gallery.
He was a music composer for anime, drama and jidaigeki from Tokyo, Japan. He passed away from renal failure.
He was a screenwriter for anime and tokusatsu shows. He had written scripts for the Anime series "Kinniku Man" and its subsequent movies.

He's a screenwriter who mainly deals with anime works.  During his training, he also studied under Kohan Kawauchi. In that connection, he also participates in anime and special effects works based on Kawauchi. In the 1980s, he was active in working on multiple works at the same time. There is a wide range of genres, from gag lines to serious ones. In recent years, he has also worked on original works such as graphic novels for men. Since the 2000s, he has been working on period drama novels.

He graduated from Hôsei University.

[Website](https://www.maocloud.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MaoCloud) |  [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/maomaowsan/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/MaoCloud)

Multi-talented freelance artist who specialized in depicting nature, such as clouds and waves.

After graduating from high school, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), and worked under [Keiichirou Kimura](https://anilist.co/staff/168326/). Later joined Madhouse and was one of the studio's leading animators during its early days together with [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/).

[Website](https://www.maocloud.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MaoCloud) |  [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/maomaowsan/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/MaoCloud)

Multi-talented freelance artist who specialized in depicting nature, such as clouds and waves.

After graduating from high school, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), and worked under [Keiichirou Kimura](https://anilist.co/staff/168326/). Later joined Madhouse and was one of the studio's leading animators during its early days together with [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/).

Hector Malot was a French writer born in La Bouille, Seine-Maritime. He studied law in Rouen and Paris, but eventually literature became his passion. He worked as a dramatic critic for Lloyd Francais and as a literary critic for L'Opinion Nationale.

His first book, published in 1859, was Les Amants. In total Malot wrote over 70 books. By far his most famous book is Sans Famille (Nobody's Boy, 1878), which deals with the travels of the young orphan Remi, who is sold to the street musician Vitalis at age 8. Sans Famille gained fame as a children's book, though it was not originally intended as such.

Was a fan of Le Mans.

Dezaki was known for his distinct visual style, which makes use of split screen, stark lighting, extensive use of dutch angle, and pastel freeze frames that he called "postcard memories", which may be his most famous trademark.

Younger brother of director [Satoshi Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/111371). He is married to the mangaka [Rikako Kugayama](https://anilist.co/staff/304119).

Non-anime staff credits:~!
Animation director for "The Visionaries" (US cartoon)
Animation for "Rainbow Brite" (US cartoon)!~

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/なかじまちゅうじ)

Founder and former representative director of Studio Liberty.

Got his start in the industry as an animator at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) in the late '70s. Soon after he switched his focus from animating to directing and storyboarding works himself. As a director Nakamura is often praised for his use of sound, and is known for some of the most notable works of the medium such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Kino's Journey](https://anilist.co/anime/486/), and [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) among others.

Following several months of hospitalization, Nakamura passed away on June 29, 2013 due to pancreatic cancer. His death was announced nearly a month later.

__Notable works outside Anime:__

- Breath of Fire IV (Video Game, 2000) (OP Director)
